values:
Tomorrow marks the beginning of the holiest of seasons, the Easter Triduum, where Christians everywhere commemorate the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ--the core of Christian belief.  So, right now, the clueless chemist takes a break from brown-nosing her labwork and reminisce (and reflect) on Easter Triduum past, back in Manila.

I have fond memories of the Triduum.  Well, for most part, these are really old memories--as a kid, I just remember celebrating Palm Sunday and Easter Sunday with my family (which can be described as "go to Mass, wave palms OR sing the Gloria after a long time, then go home"), but not the rest of the services.  Good Friday, for some reason, impressed me as a day when everybody should walk and work silently (going tippy-toe and speaking in hush-hush tones, more scared of getting scolded by the elders than by "the God who died that day"), suffering in the summer heat. 

But this all changed around 10 or so years ago, when my brother (who had volunteered to serve Mass in UA&P) dragged me off with him to attend the Triduum activities.  As the younger sib, I was supposed to watch him during Mass...and being the younger one, he was supposed to mind me.  So, he packed me off to the choir loft, with his Roman Missal and an admonition to stay out of people's hair, including his.

And so I learned...and appreciated this sacred triad of days: the significance of Holy Thursday (institution of the Eucharist via the Last Supper), the needed pain and sorrow (and the sense of emptiness) of Good Friday, the hope and joy brought by Black Saturday (Easter Vigil).  And staying in the choir loft taught me my first Gregorian chants as well--my brother's former high-school teacher was part of that choir, and she took me under her wings, if only to get me out of my sib's hair. :P 

After that experience, we went to Triduum activities every year.  Sometimes, my mom would come along.  At times, he would simply be an ordinary mass-goer instead of an altar server.  At times, I would be found not in the choir loft, but counted among the congregation, who could sing a decent "Pange lingua" and "Ubi caritas".  Attending those became a family affair.

Now, listening (and singing) "Pange lingua" in a foreign land in this season gives me a queer heartache.  For starters, I have no brother to watch for during Mass, no mother to be with.  I'll be celebrating the Triduum on my own, singing in a choir not because I was simply dropped off there.  I barely remember the Latin lyrics, but I can hum the melody.

I guess I'm a bit homesick now.

Have a meaningful Lenten/Easter to you!

For 3 months or so already! >_< Anyway, just a quick update about my long-term adventure here in Leuven--it's been 6 months since I got here!

UPDATE 1: Work - focusing on another plant instead of "The Lady"...with weird, mixed results.
- Crude extract works in mice, which is a good thing.  But on my preferred model organism for quick-screens..........well, stay tuned!

UPDATE 2: Friends a-visiting!
- February saw two college friends dropping by Leuven.  First it was Chinggay, a colleague in Chem Dept.  Next was Tricia, a college batchmate of mine (same uni, same major).

UPDATE 3: Looking forward to Spring
- I am officially tired of snow.  I want to see snowdrops instead of snowdrifts.

Which reminds me........................soon it'll be May.  And I will have a proper late-spring birthday! [/random]

UPDATE 4: *Cheshire cat smile* Guerilla cooking in the communal kitchen.
- I've begun experimenting a bit in the communal kitchen, turning out my own version of stoofvlees/Flemish beef stew.  And even started baking, attempting a Julia Child recipe for my first project.

UPDATE 5: There is no Update 5.  I just like to have lists in 3's or 5's (and multiples thereof).

There, I've dusted off my blog corner(s) (my Multiply and LJ are linked to each other).  So I can leave it again for the next quarter.

At last, home alone (The Great Escape from Leuven ended before dawn today, when my 2 friends finally boarded their respective trains back to their unis)...a state perfect enough for some bit of "reflection writing".  Not as deep as a formal reflection paper, complete with a comprehensive discussion of the given exegesis, but more of a "thinking out aloud" exercise.

2009 was the best of times, the worst of times.  Ugh, cliche. 2009 was the most dramatic year for me, if my life were compared to a shoujo manga.  So many things happened, so many major changes that marked not just my life, but the lives of those nearest and dearest to me.

I remember starting out the first quarter of 2009 by getting sick with mono.  Worst time of my life...it was my first time to be admitted to the hospital because no one knew what I had--just raging fever for 1-week straight and no signs of cough or colds.  It was also my first time to stay in the hospital alone at nights, feverish and disoriented and powerless to do or will anything.  That sense of powerlessness, of being at the mercy of others...it was a strange, uncomfortable feeling, especially for someone who is used to do her share of work, both in her profession and at home.

2009 was the year when I got the results of the IRO scholarship I applied for--I got accepted, hence my current location and status here in Leuven.  It was a confirmation for me to spread my wings and go far from the comforts and static professional life in Manila.  But at the same time, I had my misgivings--filial piety and love were the root of it.

2009 was the year the dynamics of my tiny nuclear family changed--with my brother's wedding.  It was also the year my mother broke up housekeeping, since my sib's got married and moved out of the house...and my impending departure for Europe.

2009 was the year of chemistry conferences and travels around the Philippines.  Chemistry Dept bonding in Bohol for the Phil. Chem. Congress, the PAASE conference in Manila, etc. The year was marked with professional growth in the field and the beginnings of recognition among the young ones and young once.

2009 was the year of goodbyes.  With my relocation to Belgium for my (pre-)PhD, I had to say goodbye to everyone and everything that I had close ties with...it was hard, it was painful, especially since I had lived a cloistered life of obedient daughter/college teacher/scientist in Manila.  Not to mention about saying my final goodbye to the house where I grew up.

2009 was the year of growing up.  Living on my own has and still is teaching me a lot of things which I never knew before.  New environment, new culture (in Leuven, Belgium), new friends, new work (from hard-core chemistry to drug discovery), new experiences, especially in the affaire de couer.

So many things happened in 2009, indeed!  I'm marking that year as my personal milestone year...not bad, since I've gone past my 25th year mark. :) I wonder what 2010 shall bring for me...

Holiday packing = 0 ; Procrastination = 1 ; Restlessness = 100

The Great Holday Escape from Leuven (as The Clueless Chemist would like to call her Christmas trip to Heidelberg) is nearing, and I haven't done anything definite with the packing.

Why "The Great Escape from Leuven"?  I want to escape this quaint, storybook Flemish university town, but for which reasons?  Take your pick:
  1. To have an ADMU Chem-Europe (composed of David, Chinggay and myself, for now) reunion
  2. To watch Mozart's "The Magic Flute" in Heidelberg (followed by "Candide" in Antwerp)
  3. To escape from the clutches of research, after 3 months of labwork/seminar-paper writing/general PhDComics issues
  4. To escape from certain personage(s)/confusing situation(s)
  5. All of the above
But, really, I need a break from the Leuven life, which is rapidly turning into a cheesy shoujo manga plot, in the non-work aspect of it.  Must go out, think aloud and reassess things (meditate, meditate, meditate...), in the spirit of Christmas.

(previous draft got deleted a quarter of an hour ago...surprise fire drill in the residence)

Been very busy in the past days, hence the lack of update on this corner of the internet.  Rest assured that the Clueless Chemist is alive, still a bit chilled with the autumn weather (now fast approaching winter) and busy as ever. 

But that doesn't mean that I've become a dull girl (well, fine...I think I've become a bit dull with my daily routine).  Work in the lab is still interesting, with positive developments.  I'm slowly learning how to sight-read in a way for Sunday choir (and we'll soon be practising on weekdays for Thanksgiving and Dec. 8), I've visited Ghent/Gent already with some of my Sunday girl-friends, and I'll begin my Dutch classes next week.  But my TV viewing has finally ground to a halt...almost, since if I have the chance, I get to watch BBC World News or CNN.  Evening entertainment comes in the form of music...and I can say that I have my own life-in-Leuven playlist which describes how I live here at this moment:
  • "Heart Station" by Utada Hikaru
  • "Nothing Without You" by Vienna Teng
  • "In Love But Not In Peace" by Dar Williams
  • "The Beauty of Rain" by Dar Williams
  • "1000 Fragen" by Silbermond
  • "Somebody for Someone" by The Corrs
  • "One Hundred Eight Eyes" by Cynthia Alexander
  • "Comfort In Your Strangeness" by Cynthia Alexander
  • "A Sorta Fairytale" by Tori Amos
Recently, a friend introduced me to a relatively-new Up Dharma Down song "Unspoken Definites", which also fits my life-as-a-playlist theme.

...
Come to think of it, more than 2 months have passed since I started living on my own in the other side of the world (I know the world is round and, as a shape, it has no sides). More than 2 months and a lot of things have happened, have been done.

And I face the prospect of winter holidays with a sense of excitement and trepidation.  There are times that I miss the company of family, of a sense of familiarity not just in the language, but also in thoughts and principles.  AND cooking decisions.

I still love my life here...but there are times now that I wish the situations I face were simpler and more straight-forward.

I get this a lot lately, not being recognized as a Filipina (of course Filipina, not Filipino, since I'm female).  Take your pick--I get spoken to in Dutch by shopkeepers here, my Flemish labmates assumed that I came from the US...and even US seminarians thought I'm American myself.

Oh, boy.  This is troubling.

There are times that I catch myself staring at myself in the mirror while dressing up in the mornings.  And wonder. And scratch my head. And get more confused in the process.

I don't look Caucasian.  My nose isn't flat, but it sure isn't as high nor sharp as ski jumps.  Dark eyes.  And I don't have paper-white skin.  Definitely not Caucasian.  But why is it people can't figure out I'm Asian, at least?  I'm also proud to be Asian, too!

Maybe the confusion begins whenever I open my mouth and express myself.  Can't a non-American/British express herself in perfect English, as long as she minds her P's and Q's? Shouldn't everyone express herself in proper language--grammar and syntax?  Thank you for the compliments, but I feel like a rara avis or an exotic specimen for the Western world to admire at whenever I hear that.  I know, I might be mistaken by feeling that way, but I can't help it...

Is it unusual to find an Asian female (who is not Chinese nor Japanese, not even Korean), with a university background, who is an active member of the scientific academia...who speaks out her thoughts easily and fluently?

Which brings me back to an old question of mine--what IS being a Filipina?  Because the vibe I'm getting here is that I am of all cultures and of none.  And lately, I'm getting the impression that I belong to the latter due to the lack of instant cultural identification.  True: it's an advantage, since I can blend in with the locals, but it also saddens me--my birth culture is part and parcel of how I identify myself as a unique member of the world.

So, a resolution--I will carry myself as a tunay na dalagang Pinay na siyentipiko. And make other cultures recognize what a Filipin(o/a) is.  That there are indeed Filipina intellectuals and they are not to be treated lightly, not even as rara avis nor lusus naturae. Definitely not as freaks of nature!

I've been doing this a lot lately online, during Skype video chats with friends based in Germany and friends back in Manila.

What?  Who?  Two basic questions just to keep abreast with news and issues.  My ears miss listening to (certified true) gossip either in English or in my native tongue.  Not so much as to spread the news, but to understand what is going on in their part of the world.

And they also ask "wat? wie?" about me here.

---
I've been Plurking in Filipino at least once a day.  If only to remember how the language is thought of and written. (And conveniently disguise my personal thoughts and opinions about everyday life here as a science-scholar and a female.)

"Wat? Wie?" is translated to "Ano? Sino?" in Filipino.

---
I think there's a joke somewhere in this everyday situation where you have non-native English speakers talk to each other in English.  Somehow, the fullness of expression is lost in the translation.

(I can never claim to be a native English speaker, because I'm neither American or British. However, English is the second official language in the Philippines, with US English being the preferred mode of speaking. It still amuses me to find that Europeans here mistake me for an American.)

But singing is a different matter.  No matter what language--English, Dutch, German, Spanish or Japanese--the emotional truths can easily be felt by anyone.

Which is why I signed up for the church choir in ACL a few weeks back.  Singing in English and Latin has never felt cathartic before.

---
Workwise, everything's still fresh, exciting and interesting.  And a bit stressful when one tries to multitask major things in the lab.

But there are light moments. Intriguing moments of self-discovery and entertainment.  Maybe a dash of frisson caused by a trick of the mind.

Grey autumn night, with rain.  Makes me think of this song...but I've been thinking of this song since yesterday, while working in the Pinoy scholars' charity event for Typhoon Ondoy victims.

Nothing Without You
Vienna Teng

It's the quiet night that breaks me.
I cannot stand the sight of this familiar place.
It's the quiet night that breaks me, like a dozen papercuts that only I can trace.
All my books are lying useless now.
All my maps will only show me how to lose my way.
Oh call my name.
You know my name.
And in that sound, everything will change.
Tell me it won't always be this hard.
I am nothing without you, but I don't know who you are.

It's the crowded room that breaks me: everybody looks so luminous, and strangely young.
It's the crowded room that's never heard.
No one here can say a word of my native tongue.
I can't be among them anymore.
I fold myself away before it burns me numb.
Oh call my name.
You know my name.
And in your love, everything will change.
Tell me it won't always be this hard.
I am nothing without you, but I don't know who you are.

It's just the cold, I say.  I don't mind 12 deg C, but if it's 12 deg C with constant drizzle and northern wind...that's another thing altogether.  And my paraplu died on me yesterday.

Back in Manila, I don't really relish bathing in hot water.  I get splotchy and itchy with hives, even if warm-to-hot baths are a must during the cool/dry season (Dec-Feb).

But after suffering through the autumn weekend bathing every night in icy-cold water, getting hot water again from the kitchen tap and shower stalls is something to rejoice.

Such small things can mean a lot to a tropical girl like the Clueless Chemist, really.  Thank God for small mercies!

And I will celebrate the return of the working water heater by taking a long shower with all the works: shampoo, conditioner, shower gel and a good scrub-down.  There's nothing like a hot bath to purge all the incipient grey thoughts of today.

---
It's a rainy autumn evening tonight.

The day has been a mixed bag of moods.  On one extreme, I'm so happy that Jenny got a slot at a Marie Curie institute in Germany, for this winter/spring term, so I expect her to arrive here in Europe on or before January.  Next to that is the fact that I have my Annex 15 from Leuven's City Hall, which simply states that they have enrolled my name in the list of legal aliens in the city and country, and are already processing my residence card--I just have to expect a visit from the police soon (for address verification purposes), which also means that I have to scrub down my room as well and arrange my things (a chemist's pad here in Camilo Torres is an example of a high-entropy state).  On the other end of the spectrum is the awareness that I'm almost close to broke--I just paid the rent, and, totting up the expenses for the last week of Sept-first week of October, is praying that I get my October stipend soonest.

The cold is beginning to get into me...I must purge it off like the demon it is in my system. Grey skies, grey thoughts, grey moods.  No, it's not homesickness (yet...I'm watching out for it a lot)--I do miss my family, friends, cats and books, but I don't actively long for them yet 24/7.  Homesickness hits when one begins to idealize the life back home.  I haven't reached that part yet, and hopefully I won't.  If there's one thing I love with my scenario right now, it's the sense of freedom--freedom to work with anything I find interesting, freedom to make good (and bad) choices, freedom to recreate and reinvent the Clueless Chemist a hundred times over, intellectually and socially.

(One hundred kinds of Clueless Chemist?  That's a scary thought, though.)

Or maybe, even the freedom to love.  

But that is a wholly different topic altogether and may be detrimental to my mad, mad plans of world domination.

One month down, 59 more to go.

It seems impossible, but yes, I'm here in Leuven for a month now.  On my own.

It feels weird to think about that little fact, that without realizing it, time has flown and this is where I am right now--a quiet, little university town with amazing buildings and rich history.  The place which I am in love (for now...but maybe when I get my dose of reality-check, I'll look on Leuven with a tired, jaded eye, but I hope not!), a 60-month love affair that hopefully will culminate with a hood and a diploma.

What has transpired, what has happened and what have I learned in my first month here?
  1. Leuven is a "walking town". It's actually circular in layout, that if you walk along the diameter of the town, you can pretty much cover everything in 30-45 minutes.
  2. It is easy to get lost in the side-streets.  Happened to me once, but that's one way to learn the lay of the land. :D The official KULeuven map/bus route pamphlet is the best weapon to have on hand.
  3. Buses are Belgium's version of our local jeeps. Except that they're spacious, with effective ventilation and heater/cooler, with very disciplined drivers.  You just have to remember the location of the important bus stops and the routes, or else you'll end up in a different place altogether. This, thank goodness, hasn't happened to me.  And don't lose your student bus pass, or else you'll have to shell out 1.60 EUR...
  4. You won't get run over by any vehicle.  That's how nice Belgian drivers are.  Except that you'll get run over by bikes instead.
  5. Trying to convert everything from EUR to PHP will drive you crazy. Just believe me that anything over 4 EUR is expensive (for food), 20 EUR (for blouses/tops), 60 EUR (for boots). My favorite coffee-vending machine in the ALMA charges 0.60 EUR for a cafe mocha...which is unheard of in terms of PHP.  And bus fare in Leuven costs 1.60 EUR.
  6. As much as possible, greet people first in English. Or else, they will speak to you first in Dutch.
  7. It is easy to read Dutch. But not to speak.  Beware of tongue-twisters like "Bondgenotenlaan", "Kapucinenvoer" (street-names).  Knowing Deutsch helps in reading, but do NOT attempt to pronounce nouns and verbs in German...guarantees weird looks.
  8. Filipino ingredients are easy to find. And quite affordable too.
  9. Nothing happens on Sundays. Better be ready to be bored. Or schedule important housekeeping chores.  But it's best to attend Sunday Mass to begin the week. *cough*
  10. Always wear a good coat. It's autumn, and very windy here.
  11. Predicting the weather is at best a futile attempt. Temperatures here can swing from comfortably cool (think NMR Room at NCIC) to outright cold (think refrigerators). It's better to overlayer than to go with one layer less.
  12. Keep your hands warm. By sticking them in your coat-pockets. :D Gloves are for winter.  Or...have someone warm your hands for you.
Work-wise, what have I learned...
  1. Fishcare.  Zebrafish need a buffered pH environment of around 7.5.  This is done by refreshing the aquarium water everyday with a solution of bicarbonate and calcium/magnesium salts.  And these fish eat Artemia, or brine shrimps.
  2. Sorting fish eggs. Yes, fertilized eggs are harvested from the aquariums everyday.  It takes a good microscope and a good pair of eyes to figure out which are the dysmorphic embryos that need to be disposed.
  3. Antiepileptic assay. Involves torturing 7-day-old zebrafish larvae with a convulsant like pentylenetetrazole (PTZ) and measuring their length of movement as they seize.
  4. Toxicity diagnosis.  Check fish larva's heart under the microscope and time the heartbeat.
  5. The NMR subject here for Pharmaceutical Sciences is the toughest one. But was able to help a lab groupmate pass her oral exam by tutoring her in 3 days. :D
  6. It is nothing unusual to work in the lab without a lab coat, for now. Even if you're handling interesting reagents like PTZ...just wear nitrile gloves. T_T My lab coat won't arrive until after 2 weeks from now!
  7. Chemistry is the central science. A lot of the basic problems in the lab are chem-lab related issues.  Steric hindrances, isomerisms...and basic maintenance of the analytical balance.  Please, the one and only analytical balance in the lab is so battered...making our ABs in Schmitt Hall look brand-new.
That's that, I suppose.  There are still a lot of things I want to learn here, lab-wise and social-wise. :D

"Love Talks with Kookie, David, and Oui (hosted by David P.)"  This is a Skype-only pseudo-radio show composed of three persons from the ADMU Chem Dept who are now based here in Europe.

It's hilarious, it was one way for us to be distracted from following up news feeds and Facebook stats last weekend.  And it worked, quite a bit.

But, the Clueless Chemist says "fout!" to it all! Even if it were just for the LOLs.

And speaking of the LOLs, here's David's three-way test to check if someone is interested in you:

David's Three-Way Test for Straight Guys/Girls

Negative control: Accompanied by someone of the same gender AND ethnicity, approach the guy/girl and check his/her response towards you and towards your companion.

Positive control: Accompanied by someone of the same gender ONLY, approach the guy/girl and check his/her response towards you and towards your companion.

Gay control: Accompanied by someone of opposite gender, approach the guy/girl and check his/her response towards you and towards your companion.

Oui's Corollary Confirmation on Personal Boundaries: 
[NB: This test can only be done if the said person was the first one to breach your personal space.]

On an impulse, grab the person's hand while talking about something dire and important.  If s/he did not flinch or pull back, that means s/he is too comfortable with you. 

Kookie's contribution was the laugh track. ^_^;;;;

Oh well, this goes to show that we don't just bust our heads over work...we get to laugh (at someone's expense, ahem) over little things in life.  We are human, after all!

Saturday and Sunday here in Leuven were pretty days of blue skies, white clouds and (really cold) breezes. The type of weather you'd like to kick back and relax, snuggled in a bit of wool or thick cotton.

Despite the beautiful weather, I was worried sick.  If anyone thinks that we got it easy here, as overseas Filipinos, that we have avoided the physical brunt of the typhoon...fie!  What was tough is the emotional part of waiting, of trying to connect to loved ones back home, to reassure ourselves that there is STILL a home to come back to, a family to be with, after all our work here as scholars.

A friend here in Europe experienced crying over the live-streaming radio from the Internet, delivering blow-by-blow account of what's happening in Manila.  I called home countless times, many fruitless attempts which left me panicking until that last one finally pushed through and I heard the voice of home: Ma, safe and sound.  I've lost good quality sleep just waiting, waiting for news about one of my best friends who lived in Marikina (the hardest-hit location in the metro), until I got the update right before dawn (here)-- she's safe and so's her family.

The weekend experience wasn't so much as homesickness as sheer anxiety for the safety of loved-ones at home.  And the sense of helplessness, that there are literally miles which cannot be crossed in an instant, that Twitter or Plurk cannot fully cover. Helplessness, not homesickness.

For more information (and if you want to help), go to http://www.google.com.ph/landing/typhoon-ondoy.html and check out the interactive map and the hotlines to the rescue missions.  If only by this small way The Clueless Chemist can help, so be it.

[NEXT POST] "Love Talks with Kookie, David, and Oui (hosted by David P.)". Egads.  The ADMU CH-Europe only form of entertainment.  On my expense.

She marks her Friday night with reviving her music library in iTunes.

Lab work is progressing at a smooth rate.  Not too fast, not too slow.  Already tested two plant extracts from our Strathclyde extract-library which corresponds to the local anticonvulsive plants listed in Pardo de Tavera's Philippine pharmacopeia. They look promising, but I have to check for true sedation AND toxicity.  Fish can sleep, apparently.

Socially, I'm slowly integrating myself in the lab.  Still trying to get the feel for the "relationship-strands" in the group (i.e., "political hierarchy and the power-web") but it's rather hard since majority of my labmates are Flemish and my grasp of Dutch is barely decent.  Enough to read, much to their surprise and delight, but not to completely understand conversations.

I'll be measured for my official lab coat next week.  Which calls for a trip to the Arenberg Campus, where the castle is located.  Hehehehehehe, field trip with my promoter!  This calls for Oui!mode instead of the proper!uber-polite Olivia.

On the other social side, I live practically alone.  Except for an occasional conversation with a fellow foreign student (a Lit major from Burundi) also living in the same floor in Camilo Torres, and a French scholar who taught me how to operate the dryer.  Nothing much--well, there's my weekday/weekend Mass habit in the American College *cough*.  I should go to the University Parish, but they only offer Masses in English only during Sundays. And I need my daily power!<strike>greeting</strike>pack that can be gained through a bit of reflection.

My eating habit is normalizing, with my guerrilla cooking in the communal kitchen, but I've noticed the shift to more vegetarian lunch dishes.  Yes, it's cheap, but I like how they do veggies here.  :D Even noticed now that my waistline's dropped to 29.5 inches from 32.  Drastic.  But then again, Leuven is walking-town.

...
What made my day today is news that ZK <lj user="blue_cage"> and eClair got the letter from the post already. :D Only took a week, from Leuven to Manila!  Heh, I hope the other girls will get their letters soon.

Currently writing my second cycle of letters, to be posted in October.  When I get replies, that is. Haha.

...
I also realized that I can survive autumn as long as I can take a hot shower once a day.  Preferably at night, before going to bed.

I will buy a wool coat tomorrow.  Wish me luck in finding a cute, cozy one!  I'm eyeing the one in H&M, a bit high-waisted with a poofy skirt part.  Will definitely go well with my skirts. :D

I can't wait to have my credit card in the next few months...if not December, then next year.  I'm seriously considering to get myself an Innocent World jumper-skirt, given my size now.  I don't care if it'll be late for the Sherlock Holmes movie (wah, no steampunk!loli for Christmas!), but just as a gift to myself.

...of the facade and grounds of the university residence Camilo Torres:

The sign in front of the complex.


The block where I live.  The first window above the stairwell belongs to my room.

The central park/courtyard, with the path leading to the back entrance of the complex.  This is my usual route to the bus station for Gasthuisberg.

And a macro-shot of a giant rose in autumn.  Not from the Camilo Torres, just a random shot in my SD Card.  :P And just when you thought this is still in my university residence.  No, we don't have a rose garden, only untrimmed bushes and ragged trees.

And just in case anyone is missing me in how I look and speak...here's a short clip. Uploading via KotNet eats bandwidth.  I still have a few more, but wait for them in the next few weeks.

*GRIPE*

OK. I think there's an effect already....I can see the sun from my window, AT LAST.

I just checked the weather forecast...it's not good (for me): highest is 19 deg C, with fog and a high chance of rain. Better pile on the coats and scarves, plus gloves!

Speaking of piling up, yesterday I was dressed like that...eating my brunch at Panos (a sandwich shop) when I saw a guy walk in in board shorts and flipflops. That fairly made me gape (in my head, no, I did NOT actually gape while holding a half-eaten "kip curry brooje"). Oh, you Flemish...you never cease to drive me crazy about dressing for the weather.

===

On other matters not fog-related, I'm beginning to feel more officially settled in the lab. Observed the first time how to care for zebrafish--cleaning the tanks, checking the pH, harvesting and sorting the eggs. There was a little lab accident involving tipping over a tub of Artemia (brine shrimp) while setting it up as fish food...er, wasn't my fault. Really. >_>; It's just that the person teaching me the ropes was quite nervous. That aside, I also got called in by the faculty secretariat, who now put my name in the official roster of lab workers. Yay, my student ID's going to be activated!!!

...sorry for the meanderings and run-on sentences. I wish to say that the sudden chill has rendered me quite insensible, but it's just a combination of grey skies, waking up intermittently last night and brain fatigue (from wading through the Philippine and Vietnamese pharmacopeia and finding their matches in another database).

It's one of those "prosy" days again, without the quirky lilt of poetry to brighten up my day.

Yes, I'm now in my own room for the next 12 months at Brusselstraat. So, hello to independence! Grown-up Land awaits.

But somehow, my first few minutes of being a grown-up is quite tedious. T_T I've just had my first-hand experience of riding a bus carrying bed linen and pillows from HEMA, with my backpack strapped on my back AND an umbrella. Back at home, I would have had some help in transporting those stuff in the form of my mom and my bro.

Oh, well, it seems that the building I'm living right now is thinly populated. At least in my floor (the 2nd floor, labelled "01" in Europe), I think I'm the only soul in here. Oh well.

Belated realization: this is a mixed-gender housing..........oh dear. I can bear with the communal kitchen, but communal shower and toilet? Man...my prudish Hispano-Asian sensibility is wincing at the thought.

Sorry for the odd way of writing post titles--I just finished reading "A Room with A View" by E.M. Forster today.

Nothing much really happened today...no email summons from the City Hall yet.  Egads, I want it over and done with so I can get my residence card and be free from worry!  I hate being a worrywart.

At the rate I'm going with my readings in the lab, I'll end up with a mental nosebleed by Friday. Y_Y Sorry, my idioms are all mixed up...I'm just a bit brain-tired, but stuffed with pizza and soda and amaretto.

And as for an interlude...well, nevermind.  Autumn's approaching and I get a bit sentimental over the drifting gingko leaves whenever the wind blows through the city park, or the nodding pansies on the chapel windowsills.  An elegant sonnet would have fit the moment.

*WAIL* Yes, the kermis isn't done yet.....instead, it has reached its zenith today!

Do you know how hard it was for me to resist buying a really nice and comfy pair of Victorian lace-up boots (knee-high, FTW!) for 99 EUR? Or resist a bunch of really lovely yarn and a pair of knitting needles? Goodness there weren't any fountain pens on sale so I got away unscathed, except perhaps with a broken heart over resisting such wonderful buys.

Instead, I thought of buying myself a serviceable pack of 3+1 pairs of thick cotton tights in black, with a subtle black/black argyle pattern, for 11 EUR. Wah, something useful for autumn! And 3 postcards...so some of the girls in my FL should expect something come the end of the month, if the Pinoy post works well.

I just wish classes would start soon, so I won't focus on these ephemera, however distracting/entertaining they are!

Hence, enough time to write a more coherent (hopefully) post about Saturday.

Photos of today's adventures can be found here. Isn't it obvious that I'm trying to generate more traffic for my Multiply album?

Today, I embarked on a quest to (a) locate the ALMA 1 (university cafeteria) and (b) locate the "nearest" laundrette, along Tiensestraat. Thus sallying forth from the guesthouse, I took a scenic "shortcut" through the city park, reaching Tiensestraat and proceeded to follow the road. It had slipped my mind that I'd be cutting through the Lauduzeplein where the iconic University Library and Carillon can be seen...and where the booths for the kermis are set up.

While following the road, I spotted the ALMA 1...it was closed for the season. Argh. Then I found the laundrette up further, also closed. ARGH. And so far from where I'm staying (so much for location). Walking further on, I saw another stationer's specializing in PENS. Needless to say, I was drawn to it, browsed through their collection of notebooks and pens, before lighting on the LAMY. The salesclerk picked the pink one for me...must be because of my color theme for the day (black brocade jacket over pink gingham, with mauve/maroon scarf, very un-autumn colors).

I continued walking until I reached the ring-road encircling the town. Following the ring road a bit, I turned at a street leading back to Tiensestraat, right smack on the fair proper. A lot of the booths were still closed, but a really big one was already open, serving its clientele fries and crepes. I had their fries for lunch...om nom nom, the fries were nice and crispy and so not like our fries at McDo or Jollibee.

I traced my route to Bondgenotenlaan, the shopping district, where I got an English-Dutch dictionary, resisted the charms of H&M (it was easy...but why couldn't I stop myself when it comes to pens?!) and a bus ticket to Campus Gasthuisberg (for trial commuting). I walked the whole 1-km length of "de Bond", as locals were wont to call it before reaching the bus terminal. The ride itself was comfortable and uneventful...until it reached the campus, where it deposited me in front of the hospital! A mistake! A wrong turning! O_O; This part of the adventure ended with me walking across the complex, going down from the hill to the nearest bus stop. Oh well.

Back at the town center, at the Grote Markt, I finally caved in and nosed about the weekend market (made more festive by the town fair). So many garden plants (which I just read about and haven't really seen until now, like cyclamen and ivy), foodstuff and antiques! Haha, tourist mode! Had a rather heavy merienda/snack at McDonalds (imagine my glee upon finding one!) before going back to the guesthouse.

Lessons learned? ONE: Avoid stationery shops like poison. TWO: Fries are delicious, but fattening. THREE: I should do my laundry on Monday. FOUR: Stop acting like a tourist come Monday.
No more, I should say. I need to get a spot of laundry DONE, for crying out loud!

End-of-summer night here is cold. I will never run out of rants about how cold it is here, right? Not really...I'm slowly getting used to it. During the day, that is. Without any sudden bursts of drizzly rain. Yes, I did mention that I'm officially enrolled in KULeuven in a previous post. So indeed. The next thing is waiting for the summons from the City Hall so I can get my residence card and put myself on the list of resident aliens. Hopefully I get it by next week, before the 11th. Yes, I have my stipend and allowance already as well, in check form. The problem is that it's the town fair tonight (and the rest of the weekend) so no bank is open. Argh. And, ironically, the non-essential things I bought today (i.e., the "essentials" today are an umbrella and my food for tonight and tomorrow morning) were: a book (in English, a rare thing!) and...a Sheaffer Calligraphy pen set: Just because I left my fountain pens in Manila.

First thing's first, I should go back to the University Hall and give them my (still temporary) address...unless they instruct me to go back to the Housing Service to get an attestation that I have a room in the subsidized housing in reserve. Then figure out how to open a bank account here... O_O Then go to the City Hall to register myself in their list of resident aliens. If I manage to accomplish everything, I'll try to enjoy their kermis or town fair for the rest of the day. In the meantime: http://synesthesiae.multiply.com/photos/album/44/02-03_Sept_2009_-_Sneaking_some_shots_so_far_of_Leuven

In 24 hours, I'll be leaving Manila, the ould sod of my youth, in search for deeper knowledge and wisdom in the esoteric field of the sciences. OK, cut the poetic frou-frou. But, yes, I'm leaving in 24 hours. Happy? For the next 5 years, I'll be studying for my PhD here: Of course this will entail flying, and I have zilch experience in travelling abroad. I guess there's always a first time... If there's one thing I'm sure of, it's the feeling of missing people and places that I love that I dread the most. For a Gemini, I have this aversion of saying goodbye to all of that/them. But, quoting from Ursula K. Le Guin's work "The Dispossessed": True journey is return. I will embark on the beginning of my true journey and end it by coming back. I still will come back.

A week from now, I'll be reviving my LJ posts in Leuven, Belgium.

Yes, I am currently stressed, harassed (and did I say stressed already?) with the travel preparations, leave-takings and clearances.

Excited with the prospect of spending the next 5 years in doctoral studies?  Yes.  Excited about the trip? Uhh, not exactly...it's more of apprehensive.

Good luck to me!

Busy, busy months. Had an exciting trip down Zamboanga City right after my May birthday to retrace my roots, visit dead relatives and do some bargain hunting in a barter center for formal batik malong. Returned to Manila with an awesome bang and amusing family high-drama, involving unhinging certain relative(s) sanity by an innocuous photo which may have trigged a massive load of guilt-trip on their part, and became essentially a way of thumbing my nose at their shenanigans. Mudslinging from their part ensued over the INTARWEBZ, which became a LOL-tastic source of comedy here in the capital among other family members. (Ooh, they might be reading! Please Google "unhinged", "innocuous" and "shenanigan", if you must!) (And, why did I derive much amusement about the whole thing? Because I wasn't the one who got embarrassed nor forcibly ejected from the hotel by hotel security and MILITARY PERSONNEL, for starters.) Busy, busy months before and after the adventure. Wrapped up summer class (taught senior undergrads/Chem majors), began a new semester (teaching Science and Society, if for only a few months), running to and fro government/diplomatic offices to arrange my travel documents (yay, to Belgium!), among other things. Just a short post for tonight. Am sharing the results of a Jane Austen quiz:



Take the Quiz here!

I'm supposed to be asleep, but am typing away in a good hotel in Tagbilaran, Bohol. Currently here to attend the yearly local chemistry congress since I've got a poster to present. Arrived here yesterday around 1PM with some travelmates in the department, which included EPE, IKD and a grad student (Ofel)--we went straight ahead to Panglao island, to a beach resort reserved under the dept. and joined our other co-faculty members who were already there. :D White sand, crystalline-blue water, a jellyfish and lots of seaweeds...with the Milky Way splashed across the sky at night. I'll mention something more about the happenings in Panglao in a later post, but suffice to say that whatever happened in Panglao stays there, haha. Everyone went touring today: getting a lunch cruise by Loboc River, climbing/viewing the Chocolate Hills, seeing tarsiers and Baclayon church, AND getting ourselves registered for the congress: Some shots: The rest I will upload tomorrow... ... And the best thing here in Bohol is this: there's WiFi everywhere, including the beach!

For me, Palm Sunday marks the true beginning of summer. Today has been a sweltering one for everyone here in the metro. Suffering through the heat during Holy Week is a good form of penance, I think. ... Bridesmaid updates: I've seen the teal dress (80% finished) and it's lovely. The designer (Tina Basa-Reyes) knows and understands how women are really shaped. I just need accessories. She suggested pearls, but I need more suggestions. And as for the list: I'll be having my hair treated with a hot oil and a badly-needed trim tomorrow. And be waxing my legs. ... With everything that happened last week, despite the stress and the exhaustion of being in hyper, peppy mode, I realized something: I am, after all, a female human being who after all has a emotional side to her despite her seeming bossy, weird, logical/intellectual persona. A side which drives her to kick clueless friends' shins when they say something truthful out of the blue. And kicking shins is a soul-satisfying exercise.

Today's the last day of Finals Week. Am done listening the last student's final oral exam. To not count down the days too much (and worry a lot about it), I'm taking everything a day at a time. Work and responsibilities are first in my to-do list--check exams, do grades, monitor lab work--and this helps me pass the time. But sometimes, the thought "this is the last time I'll be doing this for a long while" sneaks up behind me and whacks me by my backside. ... The lamest thing I've done for the week is to NOT make a list for things-to-bring-to-Bohol, but a list for things-to-bring-to-Leuven...six months in advance! *headdesks* This brings to mind my if-possible-must-have list (to be sourced for the next few months): - a pair each of knitted and leather gloves - GetBlued's ADMU Sesquicentennial shirt - Ladies' L/Men's XS - GetBlued's black ADMU-seal hoodie - either S or XL (the latter's long and big enough to be reconstructed into a warm hoodie-dress) - a pair of slacks - a pair of jeans - thermals - many pairs of opaque tights and knee-high socks But what I really long for, if I had extra money to spare, is this: If only this goes on sale...*sigh* The money I set aside from winning the publication awards is now earmarked for travel-preparation expenses (visa application, medical check-ups). This item is a very vain wish on my part. ... On a lighter note, I just downloaded GIMP on Viento and started plotting out the poster template. GIMP runs, alright, but Viento's puffing away like a marathoner on his final mile.

Yes, I plurked about it last night, but as a general announcement to those in my FL in LJ and Multiply: I got the IRO scholarship. What does this mean? I'll be going to Leuven, Belgium for my PhD THIS YEAR!!!!!!!!!!! The university I'll be going to is the Katholieke Universitet Leuven (aka. Catholic University of Leuven/Louvain) and I'll be gone for 5 years. The gravity of this news hasn't sunk into me yet....I'm so happy, but advanced separation anxiety is ruining my digestion. Truth is, I've studied and worked not more than 4-5 kms from where I currently stay (i.e., where I was born and raised) with my family, so this happy turn of events scares the hell out of me. (Yes, I had such a cloistered childhood [until adulthood] for a struggling middle-class family.) So, from now until August, I'll be preparing to leave...and I don't really know how to go about planning what to bring, what to do, etc. If there's one thing I'm sure about, it's that I MISS STUDYING. Teaching has its own fun and merit, but after spending time at the other end of the classroom, I want to get behind a student's desk and study...and do awesome lab work.

Yes, it's March and this current entry is typed on a brand-new netbook, a pink MSI Wind U100: http://images.msiwind.net/albums/userpics/10001/2487369681_3e6d85cdf7_o.jpg This will pull me back financially for 12 months for only Php2000+/month. But still, it's more powerful than Orihime the main laptop and looks so...embarrassingly pink. (But I still love my 'Hime more, because all my special work programs are there and I got her when I first worked in the Chem department.) ... I should write a list for myself (and possibly my mom) on what to do in preparation for the wedding. She is, after all, the mother of the groom and I the bridesmaid...and I dread the thought of embarrassing ourselves on my bro's day. Question: what should be IN the list? As a bridesmaid? Am not too sure but here's a partial list of what I need to do: - wax my legs - get a proper manicure/pedicure (which I don't do at all in normal life), Mom included - find the best pair of shoes (silver, to go with the teal 'maid dress) - drag myself and my mom to Ace Water Spa weeks before the wedding - wheedle out more info about the event from my bro and my future sister-in-law - coordinate with the designer about the design of the 'maid dresses - find the right accessories for the dress - plan out where to get the proper hair and make-up done So far, it's the third item that I've had luck (spotted a good pair, will buy by the end of the month). The rest are nada. Any more suggestions?

Another random update from my own RL, which comes in rare bursts of free time (for example, right now--while watching over a pair of grad students do their NMR lab class runs) then disappears as smoke.

...
Health-wise, I'm roughly 98-99% fine now. The remaining 2% sometimes surface (and kill) me come evening, right after my evening lecture sessions and general work.  Heck, I sleep before 12MN now, sometimes as early as 9PM because of sheer exhaustion.  Oh, and the whole experience (or ordeal) left me hating the smell of hot coffee and tea.  Yes, now I get nauseated with the aroma of freshly brewed coffee!  And me a coffee-drinker!

...
About work, we're already beginning to wrap up the semester and call it a year.  Finally.

And I've discovered (and accepted) that I'm not the ideal, pastel-sweet, gregarious and inspiring teacher.  On hindsight, I was trained since high school by no-nonsense, tough cookies who taught hard facts and rules with iron fists and left you alone to learn and discover by yourself how these facts shaped (and were shaped by) real life.

So I guess I'm a tough cookie, who smiles yet teaches with an iron fist.  Goodness, a terror!

(Although some of my former teachers who became my friends later during my uni life were the ideal, pastel-sweet and inspiring ones.  Odd, I know.)

...
And which I introduce to those who are unfamiliar with this color: teal.

Teal belongs to the family of blue-greens (equal parts blue and green).

Why did I mention this color?  Well, my bro's wedding is in May and the color motif is white/teal (with secondary shades of aqua and something like pale tiffany blue?).  And I happen to be one of the bridesmaids.

A bridesmaid.  For the first time.

I've no qualms wearing that color, but.............I just hope I don't look like a duck in chiffon in the process.

This long-delayed post is simply to inform the not-so-regular readers that (a) I am alive, and (b) I've just recovered from a nasty bout of glandular fever which involved high temperatures for more than a week and a hospital stay (in a private room, not a public ward).

But I thank God that it wasn't chicken pox, or dengue.  Still...why didn't I just catch the flu instead of this goodness-knows viral infection (by CMV, not the usual EBV)?!

Take the test: http://www.9types.com/ It's quite interesting... Apparently, I am a Thinker, haha. But why is it sometimes I can act like a silly goose? (Yes, I'm definitely bored at work today...) First thing's first: 

<marquee><font size="7">HAPPY BIRTHDAY, DANG <lj user="blue_cage">!!!</font></marquee>

...
Weekend report pertains to a new hairdo and alumni dinner-meeting.

New hairdo: Finally caved in and got my hair straightened after almost a year.  Instead of the usual hot oil, I opted to have a cellophane treatment.  Discovered, much to my surprise, that my hair color reverted to its original brown color.  No, the cellophane treatment did not have any dye or tint added, upon my request.

Alumni dinner-meeting (ADMU Chem): The turnout wasn't that big, as I feared.  But I daresay I was disappointed with my own batch for not coming.  Oh well, so much for the vaunted Atenean loyalty.  

However, the dinner-meeting wasn't all a waste--the steering committee was formed, ideas began to be tossed in for the grand alumni homecoming next year (the department's 50th founding year), people from different batches made new connections.

[And, yes, Ferds <lj user="madelung"> was there, too.  His company, and Chinggay's, colored my evening.  Max, too, was there, but had to leave to join my batch's separate get-together.]

...
To do this week: go back to lab-work, 31P NMR, and prepare the NMR class samples.

I've finished knitting the 7th color block of my scarf...will begin the 8th later in the week.  Hopefully, when I've finished the 13th (and last) block, I'll get positive news.  Man, talk about superstition...

And the weather's colder than usual...one by one, my cats get sick. :O I also had entertained a wishful thought of snuggling against someone--unfortunately, there is a dearth of "someones" out there.

It's January now...God, save me from February!

Merry Christmas!!!! (Or "Happy Holidays", "Happy Hanukkah", "Good Kwanzaa"...well, I guess that covers most of the winter holidays...) Don't forget to spread the quiet but meaningful cheer to everyone. ... And my only contribution to the Christmas lunch tomorrow is an experiment on a modern-classic: coffee jelly. It has coffee, yes...but a double-dose of native chocolate (made from tablea) to kick everyone's arses.
One of the few shots I got from attending the Lomomanila photo exhibit/concert at Cubao-X. And I really dig the disco ball.

Please, if it isn't enough that I'm tearing off my hair hunting for the most suitable formal dress for January's alumni dinner, the university just had to inform us that the Christmas party's a costume-theme one.

...............................meh. 

I have the Bodyline JSK, but how to incorporate it into an original superhero costume?  I'm thinking "NMR Magnet Witch" but I'm not sure if witches are superhero-material. O_o; Then I can wield a styrofoam-model of an NMR probe as a keyblade or something. LOL.

I should go to sleep.

Fixed it by re-uploading the icon. But I claim no ownership to the cat sketch icon (in GIF!) and will not use it unless there is a sane explanation for it suddenly appearing and replacing my default image. And this happened right after my PC decided that it is fun to have my typed letters appear backwards, for no apparent reason except to make me go "EEEEEHHHHHHHHHH????" and reboot the system. ... Anyway, as promised, this is a "make your Christmas wishlist here" post. The difference is that you are to comment what you wish for this Christmas in terms of...fics. 100-500 words, original or fandom-based (that I'm familiar with), with a specific prompt. I owe some people NOT based in Manila some non-fic goodies, so post a reminder here as well (paging Vany and BB ). But I think you'll be able to get them after the holidays, with slow mail. :d

Mmmmmmmm, was so busy with a number of things, with the 2nd semester starting and all. At any rate, I'm lurking more at my Plurk more than LJ (but I do read through my F-List!) because I only have enough time to jot down what's up with me all in 140 characters. Anyway, some life updates: - Since everything's sent (and cut and dried properly, I hope), I just applied to an international PhD scholarship program at a university in Leuven, Belgium. Gathered and sent all the documents today via FedEx, which should arrive there on the 28th, just a few days shy of the application deadline, Nov 30th! Cross your fingers and toes for me...because if I get accepted, I might be in Belgium starting next fall. - Teaching Quanti chem (haha, again!) and Science & Society for this sem. And NMR lab for grad students. - Currently learning how to knit. Project on hand is a red/black blocked scarf of alternating sets of knit and purls. - Lolita-side, it's sleeping for the moment. Broke, as usual, but on the lookout for loli-able turtleneck cutsews to match my one-and-only black JSK. - Love-life's non-existent, but that's the default. - AND I'M ADDICTED TO HOUSE, MD!!!!!!!! Dr. Greg House is my new fangirl idol on my altar, ahaha. Because he's a mischievous, crankier version of Holmes. And my mom agrees with me about House/Wilson OTP. After which....I sign out for now. Next post will be Christmas/Yuletide related (hint: what gift to give you, F-Listers).

One: An impromptu weekend trip to Tagaytay A cousin of mine thought of taking her kids, and me and my mom, to have a merienda-cena at an Italian resto in Tagaytay today. Translation: a trip of more than 2 hours from the city for "just a cup of coffee and a bite to eat". The tomato/cheese bruschetta, NY pizza, mozzarella/pesto/veggie panini AND a teapot of tarragon tea...were worth the aching back. Oh, and the fresh, bracing air of the highlands--pollution-free and cold! And the limpid beauty of the Taal (Crater) Lake's vistas! I did bring my Holga along, with a bit (one roll) of film. Here's to hoping the shots did well! ... Two: Arranging photoshoot skeds and permissions and people = HEADACHE 'Nuff said...all I can say is that the permissions were given, as managed by yours truly (which involved going to PSHS and personally talking to the CISD chief + formal letter to the campus director). ... Three: Paintballs, food trips and videoke madness last Oct 30 by the department Survived the paintball sessions at the La Mesa Ecopark with nary a bruise or hit by the marker bullets. Does this mean that I can has covert-ops skillz?! Oh, and boating in the Ecopark! So much for post-20th century feminism--the women were the ones doing the grunt work of rowing the boats. Still, it was fun...especially since we chased our fellow workers (who were in another boat) for "stealing" my camera while at sea on water. And an early dinner at Hanobe in New Manila...the beef hofan, yang-chow rice, taope with 3 kinds of mushrooms AND (drumrolls, please) the crispy pork spareribs were to die for. Followed by Wii + videoke showdown at Ken's place. ... Four: Lab work As usual. :) ... Five: Watching Evangelion 1.0 at Cinemanila with Jenny One word: AMAZING For those who didn't watch the anime series, I recommend them to watch the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy, as the creators finally polished and tightened the plotlines and re(de)fined the character psychologies. Not to mention that Utada Hikaru's single "Beautiful World" was the movie's theme song.

I have asked this in Plurk, so I'm asking it here as well:

Does anyone have mp3s of Dream Theater songs?

...
I'm sure Vany <lj user="meristedange"> remembers this--the first time we met:

It was during sophomore year in high school.  We were the (un)fortunate ones among others handpicked for an episode in an educational TV program.  While waiting for the bus to pick the "special class" up, she opened the conversation by asking me what type of music I listened to.  I said Nirvana and Metallica...

And the rest is history. XD

And here we are, after ten years, still the best of friends, with Jenny <lj user="wunder"> and ZK <lj user="blue_cage">.  And one thing that we friends still share and educate each other is music.

What prompted this recollection was a text message from a senior co-teacher of mine who was channel surfing tonight.  She stumbled upon that particular TV series featuring THAT episode which I was part of.

Man, what a looooooooooong friendship!

The jumper skirt replica of Boz by Bodyline arrived yesterday. It's a good thing that I was wearing my standard pintuck polo in black, so I wore it for a trial run (to assess quality, comfort issues, etc.) I did take a lot of camera shots of the dress for Clair to see (and reviewing purposes), but I'll post them later (indoor camera phone shots = grainy). So here's a good quality photo from the department's Sony DSLR (with a lab co-worker): Well, I did take a bad camera phone shot of the wrapper and tag (which is now posted on my office corkboard): Quality-wise, it's fine--good, thick stretchy cotton twill, chrome buckles and clean pattern cut and neat seams--but the workmanship is only at par with the mass-produced garments made locally--unlined, so-so thread quality, not much leeway for seam alterations. Plus when I got the package, a button fell off; it's a good thing I keep a sewing kit in the office, so I was able to remedy that. Details of the bodice and waist areas: Details of the back: To shell out approximately Php1500 to join the group order--it's not an easy thing, with the global crisis and all. But, if one thinks about it, a dress costs more than Php1000 if bought locally, and the current dress modes use flimsy fabrics that don't stand well in constant use. Next up in my Bodyline wishlist is a blouse to go with the JSK, a pair of bloomers, and lace topped knee-high socks. Soon, love, soon.

For starters, I'll go back to working in the lab. Looking forward to doing anthrone-assays and NMR experiments. Mmmm, NMR experiments...I miss my baby, even though there are times the electronics scare the guts out of me. Not to mention planning this out (people in my FL, care to lend a hand?). Am thinking of setting this up on the 17th or 25th... ... Opted not to go to the cosplay event in Megamall today (sorry, Clair !) because my bro and I did some house-hunting. No, we're not moving out soon. BUT...there's this house/lot being put up for sale a few meters from where we're staying. So we had a look-see, with some informative chat with the owners. It's a lovely, BIG place. The house, despite its age (>>40 yrs), has a great floor-plan that hearkens back to 1960's Manila, with more-than-adequate room spaces. But more than half of it is made of creaky old wood with flaking paintwork; the electrical and plumbing system look quite old and dubious...and the backyard is dingy. In other words, it needs a major renovations to save it, stat! Now, do we have the money to buy it? The answer is................................no. *laughs* Maybe not yet, but hope springs eternal. Lottery tickets cost cheap, anyway. And besides, bro is considering to buy the place since he's planning to get married by next year. (Ergo, no house for me and Ma! D:) But, then again, if my mom gets a windfall, it would be a win-win situation (house/lot is a duplex!)...and my cats would have a bigger place to romp. Everything boils down to cat-care, really. ... On other matters, I'll be paying for my Bodyline JSK this week, so I might get it by next Monday or Tuesday, hopefully. A sad side-note: Nay Lita, the favorite seamstress of mine and Clair's, has moved out permanently from her place in Cubao Expo. Y_Y; The last time I saw her (for a bit of chit-chat), she was sick and shocked from a recent spate of robberies in the area--she lost her valuables and other things because of it. I will miss her grandmotherly attention!

http://mierin-lanfear.livejournal.com/382637.html Yes, that leads to my recent wishlist. I would like to amend that entry. In other words, this IS my real Christmas wishlist! Those belonging to my FL--heads up! XD (1) People helping out / joining in this "small" effort for Pisay (you don't have to be a camera-addict to join): http://synesthesiae.multiply.com/journal/item/1004/alert_feelers_ahoy (2) A Vivitar PN2011 (c'mon, it doesn't cost that much...*wheedles*): http://cb1129.multiply.com/photos/album/32/VIVITAR_PN2011 (3) A fountain pen to add to my collection...maybe another one of the Schneider calligraphy pen-types? (4) Music: from classical music to old-school grunge/metal/punk...and Utada's new album (5) Cameo pendants, pocket watches....accessories to go with classic-lolita (6) A pair of shoes that look like the pair shown below...I saw one in Cubao Expo worth ~1300-ish...*hint* (7) Books you want me to read and discuss over tea. (8) Lace stockings that look elegant and not...hookerish. (9) 5-10 rolls of Fuji Neopan ISO100 120 film. Or any 120 slide film. (10) A giant sack of Friskies cat kibble. Or Tuffy's. OR...fanfics / original works done by the gift-giver. I should go to sleep, methinks.

Finally went to the traditional bonfire party of the university, for winning the men's basketball championships this year. The field was dark, crowded with happy inebriated merrymakers. And muddy. I went there, trudging through the mud, to see the crowd, sign on the well-wishers' whiteboard and listen to the uni's president opening speech. Then trudged back to drier, concrete ground...then home. No bonfire was in sight that time. So I can say that I've been to the traditional bonfire! Without fire. ... Currently thinking of writing a confessional essay of a closet-lolita, as what I mentioned to Clair a few months ago. Offbrand/No Brand: Confessions of a fledgling Pinay lolita Even when wearing a jersey, a princess is a princess... Sew frills onto the hem of your heart! Put a tiara on top of your soul! Have pride. - Novala Takemoto I admit it--I love Lolita fashion. I adore the impractical frills and ruffles, laces and bows. Elegant maidens in lampshade skirts, cushioned by panniers (or petticoats) and bloomers, sometimes armored by corsets and lacings, and shielded by well-placed parasols or fans. I love it so much that a few months ago, I finally outed myself as a fledgling lolita. Discreetly, of course, following the mode of a classic-lolita instead of following the more popular sweet, gothic or punk styles. I had two things to consider--my age (25) and my personality. Correction: three, since I forgot to put in "weather". You see--Lolita is NOT at all compatible with the climate here in Manila. Humidity is one main cause of lace wilting, makeup smearing, and other mishaps. So it is a challenge to start out in this particular Japanese street-fashion at a relatively advanced age AND weather. But why persist?... And here upon I draw a blank. I must be tired. :P
